thread.title: Jacob deGrom’s Tough Task: Beat Two Aces in One Week
thread.title_full: Jacob deGrom’s Tough Task: Beat Two Aces in One Week - The New York Times

author: Benjamin Hoffman
title: Jacob deGrom’s Tough Task: Beat Two Aces in One Week
text:
Jacob deGrom will get the ball Thursday night against the Los Angeles Dodgers , with the Mets asking him to win on the road for the second time in a five-game playoff series. A tough task, but at least this time the starter he is facing only has won only one Cy Young Award, not three.
In his first playoff start, deGrom outdueled Clayton Kershaw , winner of three of the last four National League Cy Young Awards and perhaps the game’s best active pitcher, by throwing seven shutout innings, striking out 13 batters and allowing just one intentional walk and five hits.
He will presumably need to be equally sharp to defeat Zack Greinke, the 2009 American League Cy Young Award winner and one of the favorites for the award this season after he recorded a major league-leading 1.66 earned run average, including a stretch in which he pitched 45⅔ consecutive scoreless innings.
An endorsement for deGrom came from a surprising place after Tuesday’s Game 4.
 Sports of The Times: Mets’ Young Experiment Steven Matz Runs Into Dodgers’ Ace OCT. 14, 2015 Dodgers 3, Mets 1: Clayton Kershaw Shuts Down Mets, Forcing Deciding Game OCT. 13, 2015 Roundup: Boos for Chase Utley Bring a Shrug From His Manager OCT. 13, 2015 Role Grows Even Bigger for Outsize Pitcher Bartolo Colon OCT. 13, 2015 Former Met Justin Turner Provides Offensive Lift for Dodgers OCT. 13, 2015 “You know what, it’s probably dead even, to be honest,” Kershaw said when asked by reporters to evaluate the matchup between Greinke and deGrom. “As good as Zack is and has been the whole year, deGrom has been the same.”
Photo Zack Greinke is one of the favorites to win the Cy Young award this season after he recorded a major league-leading 1.66 earned run average, including a stretch in which he pitched 45⅔ consecutive scoreless innings. Credit Jayne Kamin-Oncea/USA Today Sports, via Reuters Should deGrom get the victory, it would be only the fifth time in the era of the five-game division series that a starting pitcher won Games 1 and 5 on the road. The feat would put him in the company of Cliff Lee (2010, Texas Rangers), Kerry Wood (2003, Chicago Cubs), Russ Ortiz (2002, San Francisco Giants) and Brad Radke (2002, Minnesota Twins).
Keeping Score A regular analytical, statistics-based sports column.
